anchor.surface_text: This contention has no force. What section 53 provides is that a person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contention on no s52 liability due to agent irrelevant as s53 allows compounding regardless.

holdings.text: A person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence.

anchor.surface_text: What section 53 provides is that a person shall not be proceeded against for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence. The section does not say that the offence can only be compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation of s53; no requirement for prior proof of offence.

holdings.text: The Inspecting Assistant Commissioner may compound any such offence before or after the institution of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: for an offence under section 51 or section 52 except at the instance of the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner and that the last-mentioned officer may, before or after the institution of proceedings, compound any such offence. The section does not say that the offence can only be compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct from statutory language permitting compounding at any stage.

holdings.text: If there is a proceeding on a charge under section 51 or section 52, it comes within the purview of section 53 and a compounding of the offence will be quite within the section.

anchor.surface_text: compounded if it is proved to have been actually committed. If there is a proceeding on a charge under section 51 or section 52, it comes within the purview of section 53 and a compounding of the offence will be quite within the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge under 51/52 triggers s53 purview even without proof.

holdings.text: Even if P. B. Deshmukh was not liable under section 52 or section 22, his liability under section 51(c) for failing without reasonable cause to furnish the return under section 22(2) remains unaffected.

anchor.surface_text: under section 52 because of the verification being made by his agent and not by himself, that there was no return by him under section 22 of the Income-tax Act, his liability under section 51(c) for failing without reasonable cause or excuse to furnish in due time any of the returns mentioned in section 22, sub-section (2), would nevertheless remain unaffected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes arguendo no s52 liability but alternative s51(c) applies for non-furnishing.

holdings.text: Whether liability under section 51(c) or section 52, it makes no difference to the authority of the Assistant Commissioner to compound under section 53 which covers both offences.

anchor.surface_text: Whether his liability arose under section 51 for failure to furnish the return as required by section 51(c) or for making a false statement in the return as contemplated by section 52, it made no difference to the authority of the Assistant Commissioner to permit the composition of the offence under section 53. That section covers both the offences under sections 51 and 52.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s53 explicitly covers offences under both s51 and s52.

holdings.text: P. B. Deshmukh could be prosecuted either under section 51(c) or section 52 and the Court could alter the charge from section 52 to section 51(c).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution possible under either; criminal procedure allows charge alteration.

holdings.text: P. B. Deshmukh made a voluntary offer to compound the offence which the Assistant Commissioner was fully competent to accept under section 53.

anchor.surface_text: P. B. Deshmukh being anxious to avoid his liability for prosecution made a voluntary offer to compound the offence which the Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax was fully competent to accept under section 53 of the Act. The offer was made obviously to avert the disgrace and ignominy of a prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s53 competence to facts; voluntary based on upheld findings.
